ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS , : , : WERAHERA, GADAKAWELA WATER PROJECT: CONSTRUCTION WORK 21/'18 1.

() , ? asked the Minister of City Planning, Water Supply and Higher Education:
(a) Will he admit that- (i) a water project was planned to be initiated in Werahera, Godakawela in the District of Rathnapura, but it was suspended on the way; and
(ii) the residents of the area are severely inconvenienced owing to this?

(b) Will he inform this House- (i) whether the construction work of the aforesaid project will be expedited as planned; (ii) whether provisions have been made for that; and (iii) if so, of the date on which its construction work would be commenced?
(c) If not, why? ( , ) ( - , ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem - Minister of City Planning, Water Supply and Higher Education) , . () (i) , . (ii) . () (i) . (ii) . (iii) .

( ) (The Hon. Chaminda Wijesiri) - (1) : () (i) ;
(iii) ;
() , ? asked the Minister of Primary Industries and Social Empowerment:

(a) Will he inform this House - (i) whether a programme to provide housing aid to low income families is in progress under the Samurdhi programme; (ii) if so, the names and addresses of persons of Badulla District who received the housing aid in each divisional secretariat separately, after the good governance government came into power; and (iii) the measures that will be taken by the Ministry to provide more housing aid to the people in Badulla District under this project, in the future?
(b) If not, why? ( ) (The Hon. Gayantha Karunatileka) , .

( ) (The Hon. Speaker) . 3 - 244/ 18 - (2), - [ .] 4 - 476/19 - (1), - [ .] 5 - 490/19 - (1), - [ .] : : MANUFACTURE OF TRIPLE SUPER PHOSPHATE: PUBLIC SECTOR CONTRIBUTION FROM 1990 588/19 6. () ( () ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Bandula Gunawardane) , , , - (1):
( ii ) ;
( ) , ? asked the Minister of Agriculture, Rural Economic Affairs, Livestock Development, Irrigation and Fisheries and Aquatic Resources Development :
(a) Will he inform this House-
(i) the action taken to encourage private sector to manufacture Triple Super Phosphate (TSP) as per the budget proposal No. 211 of the 2016 budget;
(ii) whether a report that has been prepared on the feasibility study of the phosphate deposit of Sri Lanka will be submitted;
(iii) the contribution made by the public sector for the manufacture of phosphate in each year during the period from the year 1990 up to now, separately;
(iv) the amount by which the expenditure incurred (annually) to import fertilizer was reduced through the contribution made by public sector for the manufacture of phosphate; and
(v) the benefits that have been achieved through this budget proposal by now?

(b) If not, why? . (, , , ) ( . - , , , , ) (The Hon. P. Harrison - Minister of Agriculture, Rural Economic Affairs, Livestock Development, Irrigation and Fisheries and Aquatic Resources Development) , . () (i) . .

asked the Minister of Plantation Industries:
(a) Will he inform this House-
(i) the number of families in Sri Lanka whose livelihood depend on smallholder rubber industry; and
(ii) whether he admits that they have been driven to a state of despair due to the decline in the rubber industry?
(b) Will he also inform this House-
(i) the quantity of rubber for which the Economic Service Charge (ESC) was levied per person prior to the year 2015;
(ii) the amount of the Economic Service Charge so levied;
(iii) the quantity of rubber for which the Economic Service Charge is levied per person as of today; and
(iv) whether the Economic Service Charge has added more burden on the people engaged in the smallholder rubber industry and rubber smallholders?
(c) If not, why? ( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Gayantha Karunatileka - Minister of Lands and Parliamentary Reforms and Chief Government Whip) , .

: : LAND IN WILIYAMULLA PLANTATION: NON-RECOVERY OF LEASE 476/19
4. ( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Udaya Prabhath Gammanpila on behalf of the Hon. Jayantha Samaraweera) , - (1) :
(ii) ;
(iv) ;
(ii) ;
(iv) ;
() ? asked the Minister of Public Enterprise, Kandyan Heritage and Kandy Development:
(a) Will he inform this House-
(i) the name of the person to whom a land from the Wiliyamulla Plantation belonging to the Janatha Estate Development Board has been given on lease basis;
(ii) the extent of that land;
(iii) the loss incurred by the Janatha Estate Development Board owing to non-recovery of the lease from 2013 to 2015 according to the new valuation report; and
(iv) the steps to be taken by the Ministry in this regard?

(b) If not why? ( , ) ( - , ) (The Hon. Lakshman Kiriella - Minister of Public Enterprise, Kandyan Heritage and Kandy Development and Leader of the House) Hon. Speaker, I table* the Answer. * : * : * Answer tabled:
(a) (i) Mr. S.N. Fernando
(ii) The land area is 19 acres and 02 roods.
(iii) As per the valuation report, there are no lease arrears to be recovered from 2013 to 2015.

(iv) If the Government has had any loss in recovering the lease rentals for this land, and since the lessee of the land too has passed away, the Janatha Estate Development Board has been instructed to seek advice of the Attorney-General in this regard and proceed future activities.
(b) Not applicable.

. . , . , . . AFP , * . . I quote: .... Sri Lankas request to return Mahendran lacked certain information required under Singapores extradition laws and the city-state has requested Colombo to provide them, the spokesperson told AFP. To date, Singapore has not yet received the requested supporting information and documents, the spokesperson said. We look forward to receiving the requested information from Sri Lanka, so that we can consider the request further in accordance with our laws. ( ) (The Hon. The Ministry of Special Areas Development is a newly born baby. This baby has to be taken care of. This baby has to be fed with nutritious food. Special attention has to be paid to this baby. I am sure the Hon. Prime Minister will look into all requirements of the Ministry and provide equipment and allocate the necessary funds, paving the way for this Ministry to develop.

I take this opportunity to specially thank the Hon. Prime Minister for setting up a new Ministry for Development of Special Areas and appointing my Leader, the Hon.(Dr.) V. Radhakrishnan as the Minister in charge of the Ministry. I Thank you for that, Hon. Prime Minister.

[3.52p.m.] ( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Seyed Ali Zahir Moulana - State Minister of Social Empowerment) Hon. Presiding Member, the Hon. Minister of Finance, the Hon. Mangala Samaraweera, presented on the 05th of March what that has received accolades far and wide as a "clean, lean and forward-thinking Budget for the year 2019" in keeping with our country's commitment to attaining sustainable, holistic and inclusive development for our populace, along with ensuring that Sri Lanka leads the charge in working towards transforming the world by attaining the Sustainable Development Goals set by the United Nations to be achieved by 2030. The Hon. Mangala Samaraweera has gloriously set the precedent for future Finance Ministers to follow by breaking traditions and curbing expectations of the pundits who heavily stipulated that the Budget, 2019 would be nothing short of an election Budget.

As the State Minister responsible for Social Empowerment, it is with a sense of elation and satisfaction that I speak today. As you peruse the Budget, you would see that while there are no handouts, there are, in fact, various aspects of ensuring social welfare and upliftment of the livelihood of the people through holistic, comprehensive programmes geared towards micro and macroeconomic growth in that. The responsibilities entrusted with the Ministry of Primary Industries and Social Empowerment address the most important facets of ensuring true socioeconomic growth throughout the country, starting from the very grassroots.

Through the provisions of Appropriation Bill 2019, the Hon. Minister Daya Gamage, the Hon. Palitha Thewarapperuma and myself are entrusted with the responsibility of implementing our social welfare and social empowerment programmes and developing the natural resources of our country to become valuable commodities in the international markets. To do so, we aim to adopt a holistic approach, while ensuring welfare
facilities to all our fellow citizens, for their empowerment by utilizing our natural resources to uplift their lives and enhance their livelihoods.

Many Hon. Members of this House have stated that the allocations provided to the Ministry of Primary Industries and Social Empowerment are a means of utilizing the Department of Samurdhi Development, the Department of Social Services, the Department of Export Agriculture and other departments vested under our Ministry by the Government in the form of political organs. As you are aware, Madam, during the Hon. Mangala Samaraweera's Budget Speech, he, in fact, recognized and pinpointed the shortcomings in the Samurdhi system instead of exploiting these loopholes for the political benefit of the Government.

As such, the Appropriation Bill for 2019 recognized the fact that the Samurdhi, which was started in 1994 to facilitate the poor to graduate to a higher income level, has failed not only to protect the vulnerable groups, but also to strengthen and support them. It has now become politicized to such an extent that many Samurdhi officials are strongly affiliated to a certain political party. As such, this has resulted in the deserving poor not benefiting from this scheme, while those who do not deserve, mostly card-carrying members of a particular political party, continue to enjoy these free subsidies for merely supporting the politics of the day, resulting in the poor remaining poor. This has severely compromised the economic freedom of our weakest sections. Therefore, the Ministry of Primary Industries and Social Empowerment has developed objective, transparent and measurable criteria to streamline the Samurdhi Programme, which will actually facilitate the addition of around 600,000 genuine, deserving households, irrespective of their political affiliations.

Madam, further, we remain confident of ensuring equal and equitable socioeconomic development for our citizens to attain a dignified, respectable lifestyle and contribute to overall economic growth of our country. I can clearly state that this Governments policies, effectively exhibited through this Appropriation Bill, acknowledge all aspects, what makes us, Sri Lankans, unique from the rest and furthermore exemplify the Governments respect and honour for the diversity of our society in ensuring that all stakeholders, irrespective of their ethnicity, religion, caste and creed, work collectively towards the development of our country.

Furthermore, Madam, allow me to state that this Appropriation Bill for 2019 is not just a representation of the stable and promising economic policies that would take this country forward, but more importantly an effective representation of apt recognition of the mechanisms to harness Sri Lankas true potential, all the while preserving its values, diversity, culture and heritage, with inclusive and holistic development being expected from our citizens. For that, I take this opportunity to thank the Hon. Mangala Samaraweera, the Minister of Finance and further, for displaying gravitas and exceptional leadership in providing the framework for setting this country in the right path.

Madam, at this juncture when the appropriations for the Non-Cabinet Ministry of Public Distribution and Economic Reforms are also being discussed in this House, I wish to make special mention of the efforts undertaken by the Hon. Prime Minister and the Hon. (Dr.) Harsha De Silva, Minister of Public Distribution and Economic Reforms, to address the plight of the small and medium-scale rice producers in Sri Lanka. As the House is well aware, small to medium-scale paddy farmers and producers are pivotal players contributing vastly to our national economy. However, owing to natural disasters and other adverse weather conditions, there were considerable shortfalls in paddy production, compelling the Government to allow import of rice to equalize the consumption requirement. As such, farmers and producers have been faced with severe financial difficulties, becoming heavily indebted or losing their livelihood altogether.

In a swift response to this crisis, heeding to the pleas of many such farmers and producers, including my constituents in the Batticaloa District, through innovative mechanisms spearheaded by the Hon. Prime Minister and executed by the Hon. (Dr.) Harsha De Silva, the Government will allocate Rs. 1 billion to implement a concessionary programme to address the severe financial crisis faced by small and medium-scale rice millers and to give a solution to the problem of non-competitive stocks of paddy in the market. I would like to extend my sincere gratitude to the Hon. Prime Minister and the Hon. (Dr.) Harsha De Silva for ensuring an effective mechanism devised to address this burning issue, thereby ensuring that those small to medium-scale rice producers are given their fair share, all the while creating the need for trade competitiveness and growth. This, by far, is the most accurate portrayal of this Governments commitment towards ensuring progressive, sustainable and holistic economic growth.
. 2020 US Dollars 25 billion , . , - value addition - . , . , , . 500 .
Finally, let me take this opportunity to thank the Hon. Mangala Samaraweera, the Minister of Finance, my Minister, the officials who are working in the Department

of Samurdhi Development, Department of Social Services and the people who are involved in empowering and helping our entrepreneurs who are going to be benefited in Agriculture Sector Modernization Project and who are helping us in a big way in uplifting the national economy.

Gayantha Karunatileka)Sir, on behalf of the Non-Cabinet Minister of Economic Reforms and Public Distribution, I move,

"That the Annual Report of the Institute of Policy Studies of Sri Lanka together with the observations of the Auditor-General for the year ended 31.12.2013 and presented on 11.11.2017 under Section 18 of the Institute of Policy Studies of Sri Lanka Act, No. 53 of 1988, be approved.
